Title:
Phylogenetic relationships of the genus Phanerochaete
inferred from the internal transcribed spacer region.
Abstract:
Phanerochaete is a genus of resupinate homobasidiomycetes
that are saprophytic on woody debris and logs. Morphological studies in
the past indicated that Phanerochaete is a heterogeneous assemblage of
species. In this study the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of
the nuclear ribosomal DNA was used to test the monophyly of the genus
Phanerochaete and to infer phylogenetic relationships of the 24 taxa
studied. Maximum parsimony, maximum likelihood, and Bayesian analyses do
not support the monophyly of the genus. However, a core group of species
represented by Phanerochaete velutina, P. chrysosporium, P. sordida, P.
sanguinea and others are closely related and group together in a clade.
Other common Phanerochaete species including Phanerochaete rimosa, P.
chrysorhiza, P. omnivora, P. avellanea, P. tuberculata, P. flava, and P.
allantospora, however, do not cluster with the core Phanerochaete
group.
